content: American film director **Sandi Tan** (born 1972 in [Singapore](/wiki/Singapore)) is a film critic, writer, and filmmaker. After attending the [University of Kent](/wiki/University_of_Kent), she wrote as the film critic for *[The Straits Times](/wiki/The_Straits_Times)* from 1995 to 1997 before attending [Columbia University](/wiki/Columbia_University)'s film school and earning a [Master of Fine Arts](/wiki/Master_of_Fine_Arts) in [Screenwriting](/wiki/Screenwriting). Her first short film, *Moveable Feast*, was her entry in the 1996 Singapore International Film Festival. Tan has worked as the director for short films *Moveable Feast* (1996) and *Gourmet Baby* (2001), but is best known for her full-length 2018 documentary, *[Shirkers](/wiki/Shirkers)*. *Shirkers* made its debut at the 2018 [Sundance Film Festival](/wiki/Sundance_Film_Festival), at which it won the Directing Award: World Cinema Documentary. Her [debut novel](/wiki/Debut_novel), *The Black Isle*, was published by Grand Central Publishing in 2012 and was generally well received by critics and readers. Tan's novel *Lurkers* was released on March 30, 2021 by [Soho Press](/wiki/Soho_Press). She will be directing a film adaptation of [Elif Batuman](/wiki/Elif_Batuman)'s novel *[The Idiot](/wiki/The_Idiot_(Batuman_novel))*. ## Filmography YearFilm[Writer](/wiki/Film_producer)[Director](/wiki/Film_director)[Producer](/wiki/Film_director)Notes2018*[Shirkers](/wiki/Shirkers)*YYYDocumentary2001*Gourmet Baby*YYYShort film1998*Stop & Go*NYNTV series1996*Moveable Feast*NYNDocumentary - Sandi Tan at [IMDb](/wiki/IMDb_(identifier)) This article about a novelist of the United States born in the 1970s is a stub.
